strategy: Apply a neural network with deep architecture (e.g., 3–5 hidden layers of 64–128 neurons) using a regularization strategy (L2 weight decay and dropout) to model non-linear interactions and complex patterns in the data. Use a grid search with Bayesian optimization to tune hyperparameters such as learning rate, batch size, and number of layers. Replace categorical variables with one-hot encoding (only for low-cardinality features) and apply target encoding with smoothing for high-cardinality features, but do not use polynomial features. Train with early stopping on a validation set to prevent overfitting. This approach leverages deep learning’s capacity to capture high-order interactions and non-linear relationships that traditional tree-based models may miss.

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split, GridSearchCV, cross_val_score
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder, StandardScaler
from sklearn.metrics import r2_score
import torch
import torch.nn as nn
import torch.optim as optim
from torch.utils.data import Dataset, DataLoader
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

# Set device
device = torch.device('cuda' if torch.cuda.is_available() else 'cpu')

# Load data
train_df = pd.read_csv('data/train.csv')
test_df = pd.read_csv('data/test.csv')
validation_df = pd.read_csv('data/validation.csv')

# Separate features and target
X_train = train_df.drop(['Id', 'SalePrice'], axis=1)
y_train = train_df['SalePrice']
X_val = validation_df.drop(['Id', 'SalePrice'], axis=1)
y_val = validation_df['SalePrice']
X_test = test_df.drop(['Id'], axis=1)

# Handle missing values
numeric_columns = X_train.select_dtypes(include=[np.number]).columns.tolist()
categorical_columns = X_train.select_dtypes(include=['object']).columns.tolist()

# Fill missing values in numeric columns with median
X_train[numeric_columns] = X_train[numeric_columns].fillna(X_train[numeric_columns].median())
X_val[numeric_columns] = X_val[numeric_columns].fillna(X_val[numeric_columns].median())
X_test[numeric_columns] = X_test[numeric_columns].fillna(X_test[numeric_columns].median())

# Fill missing values in categorical columns with mode
mode_values = X_train[categorical_columns].mode().iloc[0]
X_train[categorical_columns] = X_train[categorical_columns].fillna(mode_values)
X_val[categorical_columns] = X_val[categorical_columns].fillna(mode_values)
X_test[categorical_columns] = X_test[categorical_columns].fillna(mode_values)

# One-hot encode low-cardinality categorical features (<=10 categories)
low_cardinality_cols = [col for col in categorical_columns if X_train[col].nunique() <= 10]
